item.title: Poisoned Air in Paris, Intel's New Chips, and More News
item.description: Catch up on the most important news from today in two minutes or less.
item.media:keywords: Tech in Two, Climate Change, Intel
item.dc:creator: Alex Baker-Whitcomb

item.title: How a 6,000-Year-Old Dog Cancer Spread Around the World
item.description: A massive collection of dog tumor samples is revealing the secrets of a contagious, parasite-like cancer that could help explain human cancers too.
item.dc:creator: Megan Molteni

item.title: The Notre Dame Fire Spread Toxic Lead Dust Over Paris
item.description: The fire at the cathedral in April appears to have caused widespread lead dust contamination, prompting a lawsuit against the city.
item.dc:creator: Feargus O'Sullivan

item.title: Icy Waterfalls Are Roaring as a Heat Wave Sizzles Greenland
item.description: Glaciologists are rappelling into a glacial plumbing system to probe the effects of climate change on the melting of Greenland's ice sheet.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler

item.title: Finally, a Robot That Moves Kind of Like a Tongue
item.description: Octopus arms and elephant trunks and human tongues move in a fascinating way, which has now inspired a fascinating new kind of robot.
item.dc:creator: Matt Simon

item.title: Jakarta's Doomed Sea Wall, Russia Takes Aim at 2020, and More News From Today
item.description: Catch up on the most important news from today in two minutes or less.
item.media:keywords: Tech in Two, privacy, Climate Change
item.dc:creator: Alex Baker-Whitcomb

item.title: Alphabet’s AI Might Be Able to Predict Kidney Disease
item.description: In a study involving 700,000 VA patients, an algorithm from DeepMind predicted 90% of cases of acute kidney injury up to 48 hours before it occurred.
item.media:keywords: Artificial Intelligence, Alphabet, google, healthcare, machine learning
item.dc:creator: Tom Simonite, Gregory Barber

item.title: Let's Break Down the Physics of a Wickedly Curving Baseball
item.description: An epic pitch by Oliver Drake of the Tampa Bay Rays appears to defy physics. It doesn't, of course—and here's how you can model it yourself.
item.media:keywords: Dot Physics, Python, numerical calculation, Forces, baseball
item.dc:creator: Rhett Allain

item.title: Jakarta’s Giant Seawall Is Useless if the City Keeps Sinking
item.description: If Indonesia's capital can’t find a way to hydrate its people without overexploiting groundwater, it’ll keep sinking, pulling that new seawall down with it.
item.dc:creator: Matt Simon

item.title: The World Health Organization Says No More Gene-Edited Babies
item.description: The public health authority is asking countries to put a stop to any Crispr experiments that would lead to the birth of altered humans.
item.media:keywords: crispr, CRISPR/Cas9, genetics, genetic engineering, health, medicine
item.dc:creator: Megan Molteni

item.title: PrEP Made HIV Prevention Easier—and It’s Getting Even Simpler
item.description: The drug Truvada, or PrEP, has helped drastically reduce new HIV infections, but taking a daily pill can be onerous. Now there might be other options.
item.dc:creator: Sara Harrison

item.title: An Electric Pickup Truck Really Could Pull a Freight Train—Here's How
item.description: Ford showed off an all-electric F-150 pickup truck towing a freight train full of more F-150s. The stunt relies heavily on one force to work: friction.
item.dc:creator: Rhett Allain

item.title: Physicists Made a Hot Plasma Doughnut to Study Solar Wind
item.description: Temperatures inside the Big Red Ball apparatus reached more than 150,000 degrees.
item.dc:creator: Sophia Chen

item.title: The Bizarre, Peaty Science of Arctic Wildfires
item.description: Peat is the organic material that gives Scotch its characteristic taste. But it's also a potent fuel that's powering unprecedented Arctic wildfires.
item.dc:creator: Matt Simon

item.title: Quantum Darwinism Could Explain What Makes Reality Real
item.description: Some physicists believe that our experience of the universe is just a big game of subatomic survival of the fittest.
item.dc:creator: Philip Ball

item.title: Great Stunt, Spider-Man! Now Let's Fine-Tune the Physics
item.description: This rehearsal clip is amazing, but something in the hero’s motion might set your Spidey senses tingling.
item.media:keywords: Dot Physics, video analysis, projectile motion, Spider-Man
item.dc:creator: Rhett Allain

item.title: SpaceX's Starship Rocket Test, Equifax Owes You, and More News
item.description: Catch up on the most important news from today in two minutes or less.
item.media:keywords: Tech in Two, equifax, cybersecurity hacking, SpaceX
item.dc:creator: Alex Baker-Whitcomb

item.title: Why Big Banks Could Soon Jump on the Quantum Bandwagon
item.description: If you’re trying to model an uncertain economic future, consider using a machine that runs on probability.
item.dc:creator: Sophia Chen

item.title: Scientists Can Finally Build Feedback Circuits in Cells
item.description: The circuitry could act as control mechanisms in safe, smart cells programmed to kill tumors and treat brain injuries.
item.media:keywords: Biology, Synthetic Biology, yeast, protein, genetic engineering
item.dc:creator: Megan Molteni

item.title: SpaceX Just Unleashed Its Starship Rocket for the First Time
item.description: The prototype, called Starhopper, hovered in the air for a few moments. Next stop: Space.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Oberhaus
